title: The Right One
text: Ever wondered what makes an ideal partner?

title: The Right One
text:
Ever wondered what makes an ideal partner?

Have you ever thought of what makes your ideal partner? Will they be the most attractive person in the crowd? The one who can make you laugh the loudest? Or the one who reaches for the stars?

Find out if what you are looking for is also what others are looking for. Perhaps this could change your mind about certain attributes. Dating was increasingly mentioned in online articles recently, making this a rising topic, one that sparks discussions. According to an article by TodayOnline, we are in the slowest decade of population growth since 1970. Based on another article by TodayOnline, the lack of confidence plays a big part as “It’s usually those who are quiet, socially awkward… they don’t know how to make themselves attractive and it slowly snowballs,” as shared by an interviewee. In addition to Zula’s recent article, “Survey Shows 81% Of Singaporeans Prefer To Date Someone Kind, Physical Attributes Not As Important, it mentions that”81% of the respondents also mentioned that being kind is more important than physical attributes” and this motivates me to further pick out important attributes to help single and lost individuals see if they are on the right track!



Rate The Attributes!
Rate the following attributes and learn more about the general rating of these attributes.






Expectations VS Reality
Now, let’s see if your top attribute is similar to majority!






From the visualisation above, we can see that our top 3 attributes are as follows:






Attributes
















Does Gender Affect The Top Attributes?


Other Factors - Age, Career


Conclusion

title: Final Proj
text: Quarto enables you to weave together content and executable code into a finished document. To learn more about Quarto see https://quarto.org.

title: Final Proj
text: Quarto enables you to weave together content and executable code into a finished document. To learn more about Quarto see https://quarto.org.

title: Final Proj
text:
Running Code
When you click the Render button a document will be generated that includes both content and the output of embedded code. You can embed code like this:

library(shiny)

# Define UI ----
ui <- fluidPage(
  titlePanel("Rate the Attributes!"),
  
  tags$style(HTML(".pink-background { background-color: #FFB6C1; }")),
  
  sidebarLayout(
    sidebarPanel(
      style = "text-align: center;",
      sliderInput("Attractive", "Rate: Attractive", min = 1, max = 10, value = 5),
      sliderInput("Ambitious", "Rate: Ambitious", min = 1, max = 10, value = 5),
      sliderInput("Fun", "Rate: Fun", min = 1, max = 10, value = 5),
      sliderInput("Intelligent", "Rate: Intelligent", min = 1, max = 10, value = 5),
      sliderInput("Sincere", "Rate: Sincere", min = 1, max = 10, value = 5),
      sliderInput("Shared Interest", "Rate: Shared Interest", min = 1, max = 10, value = 5),
      
      textOutput("TopRatedAttribute"),
      align = "center"
    ),
    
    mainPanel(
      h1("What Makes An Ideal Partner"),
      em(h4(" Have you ever thought of what makes your ideal partner?")),
      p("Will they be the most attractive person in the crowd?"),
      p("The one who can make you laugh the loudest?"),
      p("Or the one who will love you with their 200%?"),
      br(),
      p(h5("Find out if what you are looking for is also what others are looking for. Perhaps this could change your mind about certain attributes. Dating was increasingly mentioned in online articles recently, making this a rising topic, one that sparks discussions.")),
      p(h5("According to an article by TodayOnline, we are in the slowest decade of population growth since 1970. Based on another article by TodayOnline, the lack of confidence plays a big part as “It’s usually those who are quiet, socially awkward… they don’t know how to make themselves attractive and it slowly snowballs,” as shared by an interviewee.")),
      p(h5("In addition to Zula’s recent article, “Survey Shows 81% Of Singaporeans Prefer To Date Someone Kind, Physical Attributes Not As Important,” it mentions that “81% of the respondents also mentioned that being kind is more important than physical attributes” and this motivates me to further pick out important attributes to help single and lost individuals see if they are on the right track.")),
      br(),
      p(h5("Discover the best attribute to have as well as the least important attribute to most. Come along and let's find out more about you and your ideal partner!")),
      plotOutput("featurePlot")
    )
  ),
  
  class = "pink-background"
)

server <- function(input, output) {
  output$TopRatedAttribute <- renderText({
    # Define a vector of attribute names
    attribute_names <- c("Attractive", "Sincere", "Intelligent", "Fun", "Ambitious", "SharedInterest")
    
    # Find the attribute with the maximum rating
    max_rating <- max(input$Attractive, input$Sincere, input$Intelligent, input$Fun, input$Ambitious, input$SharedInterest)
    
    top_rated_attribute <- attribute_names[which.max(c(input$Attractive, input$Sincere, input$Intelligent, input$Fun, input$Ambitious, input$SharedInterest))]
    
    paste("The top-rated attribute is:", top_rated_attribute, "with a rating of", max_rating)
  })
}

# Run the app ----
shinyApp(ui = ui, server = server)

Shiny applications not supported in static R Markdown documents

title: Final Project data cleaning
text:
library(tidyverse)

── Attaching core tidyverse packages ──────────────────────── tidyverse 2.0.0 ──
✔ dplyr     1.1.3     ✔ readr     2.1.4
✔ forcats   1.0.0     ✔ stringr   1.5.0
✔ ggplot2   3.4.3     ✔ tibble    3.2.1
✔ lubridate 1.9.2     ✔ tidyr     1.3.0
✔ purrr     1.0.2     
── Conflicts ────────────────────────────────────────── tidyverse_conflicts() ──
✖ dplyr::filter() masks stats::filter()
✖ dplyr::lag()    masks stats::lag()
ℹ Use the conflicted package (<http://conflicted.r-lib.org/>) to force all conflicts to become errors

Speed_Dating_Data <- read_csv("Speed Dating Data.csv")

Rows: 8378 Columns: 195
── Column specification ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
Delimiter: ","
chr   (4): field, undergra, from, career
dbl (187): iid, id, gender, idg, condtn, wave, round, position, positin1, or...
num   (4): mn_sat, tuition, zipcode, income

ℹ Use `spec()` to retrieve the full column specification for this data.
ℹ Specify the column types or set `show_col_types = FALSE` to quiet this message.

Females <- Speed_Dating_Data[Speed_Dating_Data$gender == 1, ]
Males <- Speed_Dating_Data[Speed_Dating_Data$gender == 0, ]

#MALE DATA ##Filtering the above average matches

library(dplyr)
library(tidyverse)
Speed_Dating_Data <- read_csv("Speed Dating Data.csv")

Rows: 8378 Columns: 195
── Column specification ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
Delimiter: ","
chr   (4): field, undergra, from, career
dbl (187): iid, id, gender, idg, condtn, wave, round, position, positin1, or...
num   (4): mn_sat, tuition, zipcode, income

ℹ Use `spec()` to retrieve the full column specification for this data.
ℹ Specify the column types or set `show_col_types = FALSE` to quiet this message.

Males_Attributes <- Males %>% filter(attr_o >= 5, sinc_o >= 5, intel_o >= 5, fun_o >= 5, amb_o >= 5, shar_o >= 5) %>% filter(match ==1) %>% select(attr_o,sinc_o,intel_o,fun_o,amb_o,shar_o)

##Calculating mean of all attributes

library(dplyr)

attractive <- Males_Attributes %>% 
summarize(mean_attr_o = mean(attr_o, na.rm = TRUE))
print(attractive)

# A tibble: 1 × 1
  mean_attr_o
        <dbl>
1        7.64

sincere <- Males_Attributes %>% 
summarize(mean_sinc = mean(sinc_o, na.rm = TRUE))
print(sincere)

# A tibble: 1 × 1
  mean_sinc
      <dbl>
1      7.89

intelligent <- Males_Attributes %>% 
summarize(mean_intel = mean(intel_o, na.rm = TRUE))
print(intelligent)

# A tibble: 1 × 1
  mean_intel
       <dbl>
1       7.88

fun <- Males_Attributes %>% 
summarize(mean_fun = mean(fun_o, na.rm = TRUE))
print(fun)

# A tibble: 1 × 1
  mean_fun
     <dbl>
1     7.71

ambitious<- Males_Attributes %>% 
summarize(mean_amb = mean(amb_o, na.rm = TRUE))
print(ambitious)

# A tibble: 1 × 1
  mean_amb
     <dbl>
1     7.37

shared_interests <- Males_Attributes %>% 
summarize(mean_shar = mean(shar_o, na.rm = TRUE))
print(shared_interests)

# A tibble: 1 × 1
  mean_shar
      <dbl>
1      7.07


##Plotting Visualisation for Male Attributes (Ranking)

library(ggplot2)

Attributes <- c("Attractive", "Sincere", "Intelligent", "Fun", "Ambitious", "Shared Interests")

Scores <- c(7.637963, 7.890741, 7.878704, 7.712037, 7.366667, 7.065741)

Males_Attributes <- data.frame(
     Attribute = Attributes,
    Score = Scores)

ggplot(Males_Attributes, aes(x = Attribute, y = Score)) +
     geom_segment(aes(xend = Attribute, yend = "Attractive"), size = 2, lineend = "round") +
     labs(x = "Attributes", y = "Scores") +
     theme_minimal()

Warning: Using `size` aesthetic for lines was deprecated in ggplot2 3.4.0.
ℹ Please use `linewidth` instead.





#FEMALE DATA ##Filtering the above average matches

library(dplyr)

Female_Attributes <- Females %>% filter(attr_o >= 5, sinc_o >= 5, intel_o >= 5, fun_o >= 5, amb_o >= 5, shar_o >= 5) %>% filter(match ==1) %>% select(attr_o,sinc_o,intel_o,fun_o,amb_o,shar_o)

##Calculating mean of all attributes

library(dplyr)

attractive <- Female_Attributes %>% 
summarize(mean_attr_o = mean(attr_o, na.rm = TRUE))
print(attractive)

# A tibble: 1 × 1
  mean_attr_o
        <dbl>
1        7.49

sincere <- Female_Attributes %>% 
summarize(mean_sinc = mean(sinc_o, na.rm = TRUE))
print(sincere)

# A tibble: 1 × 1
  mean_sinc
      <dbl>
1      8.01

intelligent <- Female_Attributes %>% 
summarize(mean_intel = mean(intel_o, na.rm = TRUE))
print(intelligent)

# A tibble: 1 × 1
  mean_intel
       <dbl>
1       8.20

fun <- Female_Attributes %>% 
summarize(mean_fun = mean(fun_o, na.rm = TRUE))
print(fun)

# A tibble: 1 × 1
  mean_fun
     <dbl>
1     7.92

ambitious<- Female_Attributes %>% 
summarize(mean_amb = mean(amb_o, na.rm = TRUE))
print(ambitious)

# A tibble: 1 × 1
  mean_amb
     <dbl>
1     7.75

shared_interests <- Female_Attributes %>% 
summarize(mean_shar = mean(shar_o, na.rm = TRUE))
print(shared_interests)

# A tibble: 1 × 1
  mean_shar
      <dbl>
1      7.25
